Review of advances in bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts for sustainable biodiesel production Alexis Munyentwali a b c He Li a Qihua Yang a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian 116023 China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, China b International College, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China International College, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China International College, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China c National Industrial Research and Development Agency (NIRDA), Applied Research and Development Department, KN 67 Road, Kigali, Rwanda National Industrial Research and Development Agency (NIRDA), Applied Research and Development Department KN 67 Road Kigali Rwanda National Industrial Research and Development Agency (NIRDA), Applied Research and Development Department, KN 67 Road, Kigali, Rwanda ⁎ Corresponding author. Biodiesel has attracted significant attention as a potential renewable and environmentally friendly substitute for petroleum-derived diesel fuel. Conventionally, commercial biodiesel is produced via liquid base-catalyzed transesterification of triglycerides components of oil/fat with short-chain alcohols. However, homogeneous base catalysts are very sensitive to free fatty acids present in low-quality oil feedstocks, requiring additional acid pretreatment and neutralization steps which not only cause environmental pollution but also increase the overall cost of biodiesel production. Encouragingly, solid catalysts can provide a green, efficient, and economical pathway for biodiesel production using low-cost oil feedstocks such as waste cooking oil. The present review discusses recent advances in the synthesis of bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts for sustainable biodiesel production with a focus on solid catalysts bearing acid-base bifunctionality or Brønsted-Lewis dual acidity and the synergistic effect of the active sites for simultaneous esterification of free fatty acids and transesterification of triglycerides. Furthermore, this review article also provides future research directions that can guide scientists to address research gaps hampering the synthesis of effective bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts for sustainable biodiesel production. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Biodiesel Esterification Transesterification Bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts Low-cost oil feedstocks 1 Introduction Biodiesel is a clean and renewable liquid fuel produced from various oleochemical feedstocks, such as vegetable oils and animal fats. It is regarded as a potential alternative to mineral diesel (petro-diesel) mainly due to its distinctive properties such as engine compatibility, higher engine wear, higher cetane number, higher combustion efficiency, easy portability, biodegradability, renewability, and lower sulfur and aromatic content [1–4]. However, the high cost of biodiesel production still constitutes a major barrier for its economic competitiveness over petro-diesel [5,6]. The main reason for this predicament is that most of the commercial biodiesel productions across the world still use high-cost and edible vegetable oils such as rapeseed, soybean, sunflower, and palm oil as the main feedstocks, which account for over 60–80% of the total biodiesel production cost [4]. In addition, it has been demonstrated that large–scale biodiesel productions from edible oil may bring global imbalance to the food supply and demand [7,8]. This food vs fuel debate has prompted an urgent need to find low-cost and sustainable feedstocks that could enable biodiesel production to be commercially viable and morally acceptable [9–12]. Thus far, waste oils/fats have been proposed as the most appropriate oil feedstocks for biodiesel production in terms of feedstock availability and cost, energy balance, greenhouse gases footprint, land-use changes, and more importantly, sustainability [12,13]. Chemically, biodiesel is a mixture of mono-alkyl esters obtained by reacting fat or oil (triglycerides) with short-chain alcohol in the presence of a catalyst which may be acid, base, or enzyme as shown in Fig. 1. So far, enzymes are not widely used chiefly because of their high cost, gradual deactivation, and limited regeneration [14]. Traditionally, homogeneous strong base catalysts such as alkali metal hydroxides and alkoxides are very effective for the transesterification reaction. They are, however, limited to the use of refined vegetable oil because of their sensitivity to free fatty acids (FFAs) and water, usually present in low-cost/low-quality oil feedstocks. These impurities consume the catalyst and cause the formation of emulsions (soaps) and hydrolysis of the biodiesel molecules [15]. To circumvent this problem, an acid-catalyzed pre-esterification must be applied to reduce the FFAs content to a safe level (˂2.5%) before the addition of the soluble base catalyst [4]. In this case, the esterification reaction of FFA with short-chain alcohols also leads to the formation of biodiesel molecules (alkyl esters). In light of the great potential of non-edible and/or waste oil as a relatively low-cost feedstock, a green approach for sustainable biodiesel production has stimulated the development of solid catalysts due to their key advantages such as simple separation, recyclability, and reusability [15–19]. Although tremendous efforts have been made to develop various types of solid catalysts for biodiesel production [20–31], by and large, they still face a critical challenge of limited catalytic activity usually caused by mass transfer resistance and limited exposure of the catalytically active sites [28,32]. According to Santacesaria et al. [33] and Su & Guo [15], an ideal solid catalyst for biodiesel production ought to have a high density of strong Brønsted and/or Lewis acid groups, well-defined mesostructures, and enhanced surface hydrophobicity to be able to achieve a high catalytic activity, facilitate mass-transport and display significant catalytic stability. In addition, it has also been revealed that compared to monofunctional catalysts, bifunctional solid materials bearing Brønsted –Lewis acid sites or acid-base sites exhibit superior catalytic activities during biodiesel production from low-quality oil, especially due to the cooperative effect of the active sites in the simultaneous esterification of FFAs and transesterification of triglycerides [34,35]. Thus far, there are many general reviews on the development of heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production [5,12,15,16,36–40]. Furthermore, some reviews particularly focus on porous acid/base catalysts [32,41,42], and hydrophobic/amphiphilic solid acid/base catalysts for biodiesel production[43,44]. Given the great potential of low-cost feedstocks for sustainable biodiesel production, this review article aims to summarize recent advances in the synthesis of bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts for biodiesel production via simultaneous FFA esterification and TGs transesterification. In comparison with other existing literature reviews on bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts [34,35]; the present review systematically summarizes and compares both acid-base bifunctional solid catalysts and Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional solid catalysts specifically for biodiesel production. In addition, it particularly provides critical comments on each reported acid/base bifunctional solid catalytic material with a focus on gaps that still need further research for industrial applications. We believe this review article constitutes an important scientific contribution to guide researchers in synthesizing high-performance heterogeneous catalysts for sustainable biodiesel production. 2 Overview of the biodiesel production process Four methods have been studied to reduce the viscosity of vegetable oil for its utilization in common diesel engines without significant complications, such as engine deposits. These methods are (i) direct blending of the oil with mineral diesel, (ii) pyrolysis, (iii) micro-emulsification (co-solvent blending), and (iv) transesterification. Apart from being the most common method, it is only the transesterification pathway that converts the oil into the product commonly known as biodiesel [45]. It is important to mention that an additional esterification process that converts FFAs into biodiesel molecules also occurs when low-quality oils are used as feedstocks. 2.1 Transesterification reaction Conventionally, biodiesel is synthesized via the transesterification reaction of triglycerides (TGs) with low molecular weight alcohols. These alcohols mainly include methanol, ethanol, propanol, butanol, and amyl alcohol, but methanol and ethanol are the most used both in laboratory research as well as in the biodiesel industry [46–48]. The transesterification reaction necessitates a catalyst to attain reasonable conversion rates, and both reaction conditions and post-separation steps depend on the nature of the catalyst used. Generally, the transesterification of TGs catalyzed by bases or acids consists of three consecutive and reversible steps as shown in Fig. 2. 2.1.1 Base-catalyzed transesterification Industrially, biodiesel has been produced using alkaline homogeneous catalysts such as sodium and potassium methoxides and hydroxides. The base-catalyzed transesterification reaction can be carried out at relatively mild temperatures, and the rates of reaction are often good at low alcohol-to-oil molar ratios. This base catalysis consists of three consecutive reversible reactions. In the reaction sequence, a TG molecule is converted stepwise to diglyceride, monoglyceride, and finally, glycerol accompanied with the liberation of an ester at each step [49]. The mechanism of this reaction takes on a more direct route, creating first an alkoxide ion, which directly acts as a strong nucleophile. According to Lotero et al. [49], homogeneous base catalysts achieve higher activity thanks to a favorable reaction mechanism in which the carbonyl group of a tri, di, or monoglyceride is subjected to a nucleophilic attack from a catalytically active alkoxide ( RO-). After the attack, a tetrahedral intermediate is formed, then breaks into a fatty ester molecule and di, momo, or glyceroxide anion. Lastly, the proton transferring from the alcohol (ROH) to one of the glyceroxide anions restores the alkoxide active species. In the case of basic heterogeneous catalysts, basic sites on the surface react with alcohol (ROH) to give RO- which attacks the carbonyl group the same way as in the homogeneous mechanism. However, given that the di and monoglyceroxides anions intermediates cannot dissolve in the oil phase, they usually stay near to the positive counter ions on the surface of the solid catalyst, eventually leading to a temporally poisoning of the active sites. It is for this reason heterogeneous basic catalysts are, generally, less active than their homogeneous counterparts despite their potential benefits such as low toxicity, minimum corrosion, simple separation, recyclability, and reusability[33]. Furthermore, in the case of low-quality oil feedstocks, they need to be pretreated to get rid of solid particles, water, and FFAs before the transesterification reaction [40]. It is worth mentioning that for industrial applications, acid-catalyzed esterification has been the most used pretreatment method to reduce FFAs content to the safe level. In this esterification reaction, FFAs react with short-chain alcohol, usually methanol/ethanol, to produce biodiesel molecules (alkyl esters) and water as a by-product ( Fig. 3). Homogeneous strong acid catalysts, such as sulfuric acid, are excellent for the esterification reaction but these acid catalysts usually remain in the products and can eventually affect the subsequent transesterification reaction if are not neutralized [50]. 2.1.2 Acid-catalyzed transesterification Contrary to the base-catalyzed transesterification which is limited to the use of refined oil with the safe level of FFAs content, acid-catalyzed transesterification is not affected by the presence of FFA in oil feedstocks simply because acid catalysts can convert both FFAs and TGs into biodiesel via a one-pot process [4,49,51]. However, acid catalysts suffer from much low activity for the transesterification reaction compared with their base counterparts, thus requiring more drastic conditions such as longer reaction times, higher temperatures, pressures, and methanol/oil ratios [33,52]. In comparison with the fast base-catalyzed transesterification in which the nucleophilic attack of RO- on the carbonyl group is the first step of the mechanism, the low catalytic activity in the acid-catalyzed transesterification is due to a different mechanism whereby an electrophilic attack on the oxygen of the carbonyl (e.g. protonation of the carbonyl oxygen) is the first step in the catalyst-substrate interaction, followed by a second slower step of a nucleophilic attack of the alcohol on the carbon [49] . Both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites can catalyze the transesterification and esterification reactions [15]. It should be pointed out that Brønsted acid catalysts are more active in the esterification reaction while Lewis acids are more active in promoting the transesterification reaction if the sites are not poisoned by water [33]. Furthermore, a green approach for biodiesel production has spurred the application of solid acid catalysts as replacements to the mineral liquid acids and homogeneous base catalysts to make biodiesel production environmentally friendly and economically viable [15,17,53,54]. A myriad of different solid acid catalysts having single Brønsted or Lewis acidity has been reported for biodiesel production via the transesterification and/or esterification reactions. However, the activities of the solid acid catalysts are, generally, still limited by mass transfer resistance and inadequate contact between active sites and the substrates [55–57]. According to Su & Guo [15], “an ideal solid acid catalyst for biodiesel production would be bifunctional, containing both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites with a hydrophobic environment protecting the Lewis acidic sites from the poisoning effect of water”. 3 Design and synthesis of bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts for biodiesel production By and large, heterogeneous catalysis offers a possibility to segregate/compartmentalize multiple active sites in a single material for cooperative catalysis [58–61]. From this perspective, bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts bearing acid-base character have attracted much attention for one-pot cascade and tandem transformations [34,62]. As far as biodiesel production is concerned, solid acid catalysts or acid-base bifunctional solid catalysts hold unique potential to catalyze both the esterification of FFAs and the transesterification of TGs simultaneously (tandem catalysis), enabling the use of low-grade oil feedstocks. Interestingly, these catalysts can reduce the cost of biodiesel production by simplifying/precluding some separation, purification, and neutralization steps; thus making the technology economically viable and more environmentally sound [63–65]. Apart from the conventional acid-base bifunctional solid catalysts, in this section, solid acid catalysts bearing both Brønsted acid sites (BAS) and Lewis acid sites (LAS) are also covered as another special type of bifunctional solid catalysts for sustainable biodiesel production, due to the synergistic effect of the BAS and LAS dual acidity [33,54,66,67]. 3.1 Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional catalysts As described previously, Brønsted acids exhibit higher catalytic activity in the esterification reaction while Lewis acids are more active in the transesterification reaction. According to Wang et al. [67], the presence of double Brønsted-Lewis acid sites increases the acid strength and provides a synergistic effect, which altogether can enhance the catalytic activity of the bifunctional acid catalyst. Bronsted-Lewis bifunctional solid acid catalysts reported for biodiesel production are mainly based on materials such as zeolites, heteropoly acids, metal oxides, and ionic liquids as described in this sub-section. 3.1.1 Brønsted-Lewis acidic bifunctional ionic liquids (ILs) Recently, supported bifunctional ionic liquids with Brønsted –Lewis dual-acid sites (BLAIL) have attracted significant attention for biodiesel production from oil feedstocks with high FFA content. For instance, Zhang et al. [68] synthesized a Brønsted-Lewis acidic biofunctional ionic liquid catalyst (IL/Fe-SBA-15) by immobilizing Brønsted acidic IL 1-(propyl-3-sulfonate)-3-(3-trimethoxysilylpropyl) imidazolium hydrogen sulfate ([SO3H-PIm-CPMS] [HSO4]) on Fe-SBA-15. This catalyst achieved a conversion efficiency of 87.7% in the esterification reaction of oleic acid with methanol under optimal reaction conditions ( Table 1 , Entry 1). When compared with the IL supported only on SBA-15, IL/Fe-SBA-15 showed a higher catalytic activity despite having fewer Brønsted acidic sites. This superior catalytic performance was attributed to the cooperative effect of Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites. Nevertheless, it should be noted that the IL/Fe-SBA-15 catalyst was not tested for the transesterification reaction as the main chemical reaction involved in biodiesel production from lipid sources, thus necessitating further research to evaluate its catalytic performance in an actual biodiesel production process. Another Brønsted-Lewis acidic catalyst, [(CH2COOH)2IM]HSO4 @H-UiO-66, was constructed via bidentate coordination between one -COO-group of [(CH2COOH)2IM]HSO4 and two portions of unsaturated Zr ion defects of the hierarchically porous Zr metal-organic framework (H-UiO-66) as shown in Fig. 4 [69] . Under optimal conditions (Table 1, Entry 2), [(CH2COOH)2IM]HSO4 @H-UiO-66 achieved a biodiesel yield of 93.71% in the esterification of oleic acid with methanol. This yield decreased to 90.95% after five runs, indicating the good reusability of this Brønsted-Lewis acidic bifunctional catalyst. Similarly, this study did not investigate the catalytic activity in any transesterification reaction. Novel Brønsted-Lewis acidic ionic liquid catalysts prepared using Brönsted acidic IL [BSO3HMIM]HSO4 with various metal sulfates were also reported [70]. [BSO3HMIM]HSO4–Fe2(SO4)3 exhibited superior catalytic activity in biodiesel production from a non-food feedstock (Camptotheca acuminate seed oil) with a high conversion yield (95.7%) only after 60 min at a relatively low temperature of 60 °C and assisted by microwave (Table 1, Entry 3). A series of Brønsted-Lewis acidic ionic liquid catalysts ([SO3H-pmim]Cl-xSnCl2 (x = 0–0.8) were synthesized by coupling SnCl2 (as a Lewis acid center) with SO3H-functionalized zwitterion ionic liquid (as a Brønsted acid) [71]. In this series, [HSO3-pmim]Cl-0.7SnCl2 was found highly effective in the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol and achieved an excellent biodiesel yield of 98.6% under optimized conditions (Table 1, Entry 4), thanks to the cooperative catalysis of BAS and LAS. BLAIL catalysts were also synthesized by immobilizing different amounts of sulfonic acid functionalized imidazolium hydrogen sulfate ([Ps-im] HSO4) on an acidic mesoporous organosilica support material [SO4 2−/ZrO2-SiO2(Et)] by chemical grafting [72], as shown in Fig. 5. The best performing catalyst [SO4 2-/ZrO2-SiO2(Et)-Ps-im]HSO4 reached an excellent biodiesel yield of 98.99% in the transesterification reaction of soybean oil with methanol under optimized reaction conditions (Table 1, Entry 5). This high catalytic activity was ascribed to the presence of Brønsted-Lewis dual-acidic sites coupled with large BET surface area, ordered mesoporous structure, and hydrophobicity of the organic-inorganic hybrid material, which are all favorable for the adsorption of bulky oleophilic substrates to reach the active sites during the transesterification reaction. By combining molecular simulation with experiments, Cai et al. [73] designed and synthesized an efficient Brønsted-Lewis acid IL catalyst: [Ps-MTH][CF3SO3]-FeCl3 (x = 0.65) for biodiesel production from soapberry oil. In line with the experimental data, molecular simulation using electrostatic potential and proton affinity analyses proved 4-methylthiazole (MT) to be the best matrix for the IL preparation. [Ps-MTH][CF3SO3]-FeCl3 (x = 0.65) achieved 97% biodiesel yield under optimal conditions (Table 1, Entry 6), obtained by using Box-Behnken response surface methodology. This catalyst exhibited excellent reusability and could retain 96% of its initial activity after 5 cycles. In this study, the authors further clarified the transesterification mechanism with the prepared Brønsted-Lewis acidic IL catalyst as illustrated in Fig. 6 . In path I, the Brønsted acid group could provide an H+ ion to protonate the carbonyl group and give a carbocation. Then, following a nucleophilic attack of the methanol molecule, a tetrahedral intermediate could be formed and then decompose to give the product and H+. Comparably, in path II, the Lewis acid site (Fe3+) could create a carbocation followed by a nucleophilic attack of methanol. Lastly, a tetrahedral intermediate could be formed and subsequently decompose into the product and Fe3+. It is worth mentioning that the hydrogen bond established between the hydroxide radical of methanol and fluorine atom of trifluoromethane sulfonate facilitated the nucleophilic attack in this mechanism. For biodiesel production from high FFA content oil feedstocks via simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions, other various Brønsted-Lewis acidic ionic liquid catalysts have also been reported. (3–Sulfonic acid)–propyltriethylammonium chloroironinate [HO3S–(CH2)3–NEt3]Cl–FeCl3 with a FeCl3 molar fraction of 0.67 was applied in one-pot biodiesel production from waste oil with 34.6 mg KOH/g acidic value, and eventually achieved 95% biodiesel yield at 120 °C within 4 h along with excellent reusability (Table 1, Entry 7). This high catalytic performance was ascribed to the cooperative catalysis of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [74]. Hu et al. [75] also synthesized a Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional catalyst ([DSI][FeCl4]) from 1,3-disulfonic acid imidazolium chloride ([DSI][Cl]) with FeCl3 via a facile and atom- economical process. This catalyst was applied as a solid catalyst for one-pot conversion of Firmiana platanifolia L.f. (FPLF) oil to biodiesel. To deal with mass transfer resistance, in this study, biomass-derived tetrahydrofuran (THF) was used as a co-solvent. Under optimized conditions (Table 1, Entry 8), [DSI][FeCl4] achieved a high biodiesel yield of 98.7% through simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions, outperforming two commercial acid resins (Amberlyst 15 and Nafion NR50). The higher catalytic performance of [DSI][FeCl4] was attributed to the synergistic effect of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites as well as the use of co-solvent (THF), which altogether lowered the reaction temperature and shortened the reaction time. [DSI][FeCl4] acted as a heterogeneous catalyst and maintained a high catalytic activity after four cycles. Furthermore, one of the critical bottlenecks of ionic liquids-based solid catalysts is their difficult separation and recovery which limit their widespread applications as heterogeneous catalysts [76,77]. To address this challenge, magnetic materials have been used as catalyst support to enable the simple separation of some ionic liquid catalysts bearing the Brønsted-Lewis acid sites by simply applying an external magnetic field [78,79]. In this context, a magnetically recyclable solid catalyst (FS-B-L-IL) was synthesized by immobilizing a Brønsted-Lewis acidic ionic liquid (IL) on magnetic Fe3O4 @SiO2 [80]. This bifunctional and magnetically recoverable solid acidic catalyst was tested for biodiesel production from Koelreuteria integrifoliola oil with a high acid value (AV) of 4.66 mg KOH/g. Under optimal conditions (Table 1, Entry 9), the FS-B-L-IL catalyst displayed high activity in converting the crude K. integrifoliola seed oil into biodiesel (FAME yield of 93.7%) via simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions. Impressively, the solid catalyst displayed heterogeneous catalytic behavior and could be easily recycled at least five times without any remarkable loss of activity. What is more, the main properties of K. integrifoliola biodiesel produced over FS-B-L-IL were in line with the ASTM D6751 and EN 14214 specifications. In an attempt to develop highly active and stable heterogeneous acid catalysts for sustainable biodiesel production, Zhang et al. [81] synthesized magnetically recyclable acidic polymeric ionic liquids with different hydrophobicity and controllable acidity (Fnm-PILs) via radical polymerization and anion exchange. FnmS-PIL (1a, C8) afforded 91.7% biodiesel yield in concurrent esterification and transesterification of crude Euphorbia lathyris L. seed oil (CELO) thanks to its good physical-chemical properties, especially strong acid strength from a high number of its Brønsted –Lewis dual-acidic sites, and strong hydrophobicity. More importantly, the catalyst was simply recovered using an external magnet and displayed excellent reusability (Table 1, Entry 10). A Brønsted-Lewis acid heterogeneous catalyst ([DSIM][FeCl4]/SBA-15) possessing a large specific surface area and mesoporous structure was synthesized by using imidazole ferric salts as the active components and SBA-15 as support [82]. The solidification of the ionic liquid by the introduction of metal was an effective strategy for accommodating both the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in the same catalyst to explore their synergistic effect for biodiesel production via the esterification of oleic acid with methanol. The conversion of oleic acid over [DSIM][FeCl4]/SBA-15 could reach 98.2% just after 4 h at 70 °C. This high catalytic activity was ascribed to the synergy of dual Brønsted-lewis acidic sites, large specific surface area, and abundant mesoporous channels of the catalyst. Besides, the catalyst could still achieve 85.5% of conversion efficiency after 5 cycles, demonstrating its good stability and reusability. Recently, a magnetically recyclable catalyst composed of polyoxometalate (POM)-based sulfonated ionic liquids (ILs) bearing Brønsted -Lewis acid sites [CoFe2O4/MIL-88B(Fe)-NH2/(Py-Ps)PMo] was reported for biodiesel production via transesterification of soybean oil and esterification of FFAs [83]. This bifunctional solid acid catalyst was prepared by loading polyoxometalate ((Py-Ps)PMo) on an amino-functionalized metal-organic framework ((CoFe2O4/MIL-88B(Fe)-NH2) as shown in Fig. 7. Under optimal conditions, CoFe2O4/MIL-88B(Fe)-NH2 achieved an oil conversion efficiency of 95.6% and a complete conversion of FFAs (Table 1, Entry 12). The catalytic performance was attributed to the combination of the acidity of the Brönsted-Lewis acidic sites and a porous structure of the magnetic support. The amino groups on the CoFe2O4/ MIL-88B(Fe)-NH2 support not only improved the ILs dispersion but also reduced the loss of ILs during the reaction process, and eventually improved the catalytic stability of the solid catalyst. Interestingly, the catalyst was simply recovered by using an external magnet thanks to its superparamagnetic property. It should be noted that although most of the reported Brønsted-Lewis acidic bifunctional ionic liquid catalysts demonstrated high catalytic performance for biodiesel production, by and large, the high cost of ionic liquids and complex catalyst preparation processes constitute a major challenge for their industrial application in the context of making biodiesel production cost-competitive. 3.1.2 Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional metal oxides Metal oxides have been extensively used as catalysts/catalyst supports on account of their typical characteristics such as high thermal and mechanical stability, high specific surface area, and large pore size and pore volume [37,84]. Acid-functionalized metal oxides such as sulfated metal oxides and other metal oxides-supported solid acids have been studied as solid acid catalysts for efficient biodiesel production from low-grade oils, especially due to their strong Brønsted–Lewis dual acidity [85]. 3.1.2.1 Sulfated metal oxides It has been revealed that the modification of transition metal oxide surfaces by the sulfate group enhances the Brønsted acidity and increases the strength of Lewis acidity because of the inductive effect of SO bonds as shown in Fig. 8 [86–90] . In these Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional metal oxides, the electronegativity of a metallic element greatly influences the Brønsted acid strength. A lower electronegativity value implies a weaker MOH bond (M= Zr, Ta, Nb, or Ti) and, hence, the proton can be released quite easily. This is why electronegativity order of the metals: Zr (1.33) < Ta (1.50) < Ti (1.54) < Nb (1.60) is utterly consistent with the Brønsted acid strength order of the corresponding sulfated metal oxides: (SO4 2-/ZrO2 > SO4 2-/Ta2O5 > SO4 2-/Nb2O5 > SO4 2-/TiO2) [15,91]. SO4 2-/ZrO2 has the highest Brønsted acid strength among various sulfated metal oxides, and it is the most commonly used for biodiesel synthesis. It is important to mention that like the Brønsted acidic sites, Lewis acidic sites within SO4 2-/MOx are also able to catalyze the esterification of FFAs and transesterification of TGs during biodiesel production from lipid sources with high FFA content. Jitputti et al. [92] examined the catalytic activities of ZrO2, ZnO, SO4 2−/SnO2, SO4 2−/ZrO2, KNO3/KL zeolite, and KNO3/ZrO2 as solid catalysts for the transesterification of crude palm kernel oil (CPKO) and crude coconut oil (CCO) with methanol. Among these catalysts, SO4 2−/ZrO2 attained the highest ester content, 90.3 wt% from the CPKO and 86.3 wt% from the CCO. However, the study showed that SO4 2−/ZrO2 cannot be directly reused mainly due to the leaching of acidic sites and their deactivation by the adsorption of the products & reactants. SO4 2−/ZrO2 was also investigated in the transesterification of tricaprylin (TCP) with a series of aliphatic alcohols (methanol, ethanol, and n-butanol) [93]. Similarly, the poor stability/reusability of SO4 2−/ZrO2 in the esterification and/or transesterification was also reported by other research groups [94,95]. It was subsequently noticed that the leaching of acidic sites was linked to the conventional preparation route of SO4 2−/ZrO2-based catalysts by a post-synthesis grafting method followed by calcination. Indeed, the high calcination temperature (600–650 °C) weakens the interactions between SO4 2- ion and ZrO2 framework, thereby leading to poor catalytic stability [15,96]. Henceforth, a quest for new preparation methods and more suitable preparation conditions for enhancing the catalytic activity and stability of SO4 2−/ZrO2–based catalysts especially for biodiesel production has attracted great interest from many research groups. For instance, Li et al. [91] synthesized a series of mesoporous sulfated zirconia-based hybrid catalysts functionalized by alkyl-bridged organosilica moieties (SO4 2-/ZrO2SiO2 (R) via a one-step co-condensation technique followed by hydrothermal treatment in the presence of a triblock copolymer surfactant (P123). Contrary to the sample prepared by the post-synthetic grafting method, the interaction between the sulfate group and the ZrO2 support within (SO4 2-/ZrO2SiO2(R) was stronger, and the leaching of the sulfate group from the ZrO2 framework was effectively prohibited. Tested in the methanolysis of pure triglyceride (tripalmitin) and low-cost virgin plant oil (Eruca sativa Gars. oil), (SO4 2-/ZrO2SiO2(R) catalysts displayed better catalytic activities attributed to their enhanced acidity and increased hydrophobicity. What is more, the used one pot co-condensation method effectively inhibited the loss of acidic sites and enabled SO4 2-/ZrO2SiO2(R) to be reused as a heterogeneous catalyst. However, it should be noted that the introduction of alkyl groups (R) in the SO4 2-/ZrO2 mesostructure reduced pore diameter and led to the lack of long-range structural ordering, which consequently required a quite long reaction time (24 h) to attain significant biodiesel yields. Therefore, for industrial application, further research may look at how to reduce mass transfer limitations of bulky FFAs and TGs molecules for improving the activity of SO4 2-/ZrO2SiO2(R) catalysts. A stable calcined zirconium sulfate supported on MCM-41 silica was also reported for biodiesel production via ethanolysis of sunflower oil with high FFA and water content [97]. This study found that the thermal decomposition of zirconium sulfate led to the formation of monoclinic/tetragonal zirconia with some sulfate ions strongly retained. Under optimized reaction conditions (Table 1 , Entry 13), Zr30-MCM catalyst (where 30 is the weight percentage of zirconium sulfate precursor) exhibited a high biodiesel yield (91.5%) and enhanced stability. Although the catalyst exhibited a partial loss of activity (25%) after the first cycle, the activity was later recovered in the third cycle to attain 79% of the conversion achieved by the fresh catalyst. A novel and efficient method to prepare tetragonal sulfated zirconia by direct impregnation of ammonium persulphate on crystalline zirconia followed by calcination at the temperature range of 300–500 °C was reported by Liang et al. [98]. This preparation route presented an important advantage of preventing phase transition from tetragonal to monoclinic phase and led to a tetragonal structure of zirconia with high crystallinity and super acidity. The catalyst calcined at 500 °C (SCZ-500) displayed high catalytic activity, it could achieve the highest FAME yield of 84.6% in the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol, attributed to its high super-acidity. However, the study did not evaluate the catalyst stability and reusability as other key features that characterize potential solid catalysts. Very recently, a nano-sulfated zirconium catalyst (ferric-manganese-doped sulfated zirconia, Fe-Mn-SO4/ZrO2) was prepared via a wetness impregnation method and applied for biodiesel production from tannery waste sheep fat [99]. The catalyst exhibited an excellent biodiesel yield of 98.7% after 5 h and could be easily recovered with the help of a permanent magnet. Moreover, after 5 catalytic cycles, the reused catalyst gave 90 wt% biodiesel yield with a catalyst recovery of 88 wt%, demonstrating its superior recyclability and reusability (Table 1, Entry 15). Rabee et al. [100] synthesized sulfated zirconia (SZ) by impregnation of Zr(OH)4 with (NH4)2SO4 and applied it as a solid acid catalyst in propanoic acid esterification with methanol to gain new insights into the structure-activity relationship. Methylbutynol (MBOH) reactive titration revealed that the intermediate 1.7 wt% S loading led to strong Brønsted-Lewis acid pairs upon completion of the sulfate monolayer, which enabled the optimum 1.7 wt% SZ catalyst to achieve high catalytic performance and reusability. Interestingly, the catalytic activity in the propanoic acid esterification directly correlated with acid strength, which in turn, coincided with the formation of Brønsted-Lewis acid pairs. It is worth mentioning that apart from SO4 2-/ZrO2, a myriad of sulfated oxides of other metals such as SO4 2-/TiO2 [101–105] , SO4 2-/SnO2 [106,107], SO4 2-/ZnO [108], SO4 2-/Nb2O5 [109] , or of mixed metals such as SO4 2-/SnO2-ZrO2 [110] , and SO4 2−/Al2O3–SnO2 [111] , bearing the Brønsted-Lewis dual acidity, have also been synthesized and they exhibited considerable performance for biodiesel production. Nevertheless, by and large, the catalytic application of sulfated metal oxides is still limited by some issues such as poor stability, and lack of suitable porosity and surface hydrophobicity; which cap their catalytic performance to achieve higher biodiesel yields under mild operational conditions. 3.1.2.2 Mixed metal oxides and metal oxides-supported solid acid catalysts In addition to the sulfated metal oxides, researchers have also been synthesizing a wide range of mixed metal oxides and metal oxide-supported solid acid materials with the Brønsted–Lewis dual acidity, as potential solid catalysts for biodiesel production. For instance, Furuta et al. [112] prepared tungstated zirconia (WO3/ZrO2) and compared it with sulfated tin and zirconium oxides (SO4/SnO2, SO4/ZrO2) in the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol and esterification of n-octanoic acid with methanol. It should be noted that although the tungstated zirconia–alumina catalyst displayed the highest activities in the esterification reaction (~ 100% yield) and conversion of soybean oil (90%) thanks to its super-acid character, it required very harsh conditions (high temperature: 200–3000 C, and long reaction time: 20 h) which are not attractive for its industrial catalytic application. Similar to the sulfated zirconia (SO4 2-/ZrO2), WOx/ZrO2 also possesses dual Brønsted –Lewis acidity. Its Brønsted acidity is attributed to the delocalized protons that are connected with the WOx network, while its strong Lewis acid sites are the tungsten (W) elements [89,113]. WOx/ZrO2 solid catalysts with various tungsten loadings were prepared via incipient-wetness impregnation of zirconium hydroxide and subsequently applied for the esterification of palmitic acid with methanol [114]. The Brönsted: Lewis ratio displayed a volcano dependence on loading, reaching a maximum at 15.3 wt% W, but calcination at 800 0C dramatically increased the Brönsted character as shown in Fig. 9. The optimum 15 wt% WOx/ZrO2 led to the saturation of polymeric tungsten species (WO3) supported on tetragonal zirconia and provided the maximum Brönsted: Lewis acid site ratio required for the palmitic acid esterification. Interestingly, 15 wt% WOx/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited high leaching resistance and could be easily recycled without major activity loss. However, the catalyst was not tested in any transesterification reaction just to get a sense of its catalytic performance in a typical industrial biodiesel production process. Guldhe et al. [115] tested WO3/ZrO2 for the conversion of S. obliquus lipids into biodiesel, and compared its catalytic performance to H2SO4 and immobilized Pseudomonas fluorescence lipase as homogenous and enzyme catalysts, respectively. Under optimal reaction conditions (Table 1, Entry 19), WO3/ZrO2 afforded a maximum biodiesel yield of 94.58%, comparable to the homogeneous catalyst’s yield but higher to the yield of the biological catalyst. It is worth noting that while WO3/ZrO2 achieved high conversion efficiency, it required the highest temperature and exhibited limited stability, indicating a need for further research to attain its industrial catalytic application. Niobium(V) oxide (Nb2O5) modified mesoporous SBA-15 solid acid catalysts having both Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites were prepared via wet impregnation with NbCl5 (2–32 wt% Nb), followed by calcination [116]. The Brönsted: Lewis ratio was found to be dependent on both Nb loading and calcination temperature. When applied in the esterification reaction of propanoic acid with methanol as a model reaction for biodiesel production, the catalyst with 2 wt% Nb loading calcined at 500 °C (2 Nb/SBA-15 (500)) exhibited the best catalytic performance attributed to the highest Brønsted/Lewis ratio of 4. 2 Nb/SBA-15 (500) also displayed excellent reusability of achieving 92% yield after 4 consecutive runs without remarkable deactivation. The catalyst stability was ascribed to the formation of the SiONb bond derived from the reaction of niobium precursor with surface silanol groups. However, 2 Nb/SBA-15 still needs to be investigated for transesterification reaction to get a sense of its actual catalytic performance in a typical industrial biodiesel production process. 3.1.3 Brønsted-Lewis bifunctional heteropoly acids Heteropoly acids (HPAs) are free acidic forms of polyoxometalates (POMs), which have proven to possess both super acidity (pKH+ ˃ 12 ) and flexible structures [117]. Notably, HPAs having anions with Keggin structure (Keggin HPAs) are strong Brønsted acids with good thermal stability that have been widely investigated as solid catalysts in various acid-catalyzed reactions [118,119]. However, low surface area (1–10 m2/g) and high solubility in polar media limit the application of original heteropoly acids as heterogeneous acid catalysts in organic transformations such as biodiesel production. In an attempt to address these critical drawbacks, heteropoly acids are supported on some high-surface-area matrices, but this approach only improves the surface area and modulates the acid sites densities, while the solubility issue can still affect their catalytic activity and stability [27,120–124]. Ion-exchanging large cations into Keggin type HPAs has proven to be an attractive approach to synthesize insoluble salts of HPAs that exhibit good chemical stability when used as solid catalysts. In addition, introducing metals with Lewis acidity into heteropoly acids (modular grafting of Lewis acidic cations) could increase and diversify the acidity (Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctionality) of HPAs and enable them to promote, more effectively, acid-catalyzed transformations including biodiesel production [125–127]. For instance, zinc dodecatungstophosphate (Zn1.2H0.6PW12O40; ZnPW) nanotubes were prepared using cellulose fibers as a template and tested as solid catalysts for biodiesel production from waste cooking oil containing 26.89% free fatty acids and 1% moisture [128]. Impressively, under mild conditions (Table 1, Entry 20), ZnPW exhibited high catalytic activity (98% conversion) in biodiesel production via simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions, thanks to its high acid strength from the double Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, high surface area, and nanostructure. The catalyst could be easily recycled and reused with 94.3% oil conversion after five successive catalytic cycles. Similarly, zirconium dodecatungstophosphate Zr0.7H0.2PW12O40, abbreviated as ZrHPW, was employed as a heteropolyacid nanoreactor for biodiesel production from low-quality oil feedstock [129]. This nanotube catalyst reduced FFA content from 26.89 to 0.3 wt% via esterification, and achieved a 98.5% conversion efficiency in the transesterification of triglycerides, under mild conditions (Table 1, Entry 21). The high catalytic activity and stability of ZrHPW were attributed to the presence of uniformly distributed nanochannels and high acid strength derived from double Brønsted-Lewis acid sites. Shi et al. [130] synthesized some salts of H3PW12O40-Mx/nH3–xPW12O40, denoted as Mx/nH3–xPW, and used them to study the effect of Brønsted and Lewis acidity on the catalytic activity of heteropoly acids in transesterification and esterification reactions. The study found that both Lewis and Brønsted acidity are suitable for the conversion of waste cooking oil into biodiesel. However, HPAs containing cations of moderate Lewis acidity such as Ti.HPAs exhibited superior catalytic activity in the conversion of waste cooking oil via simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions. This finding was congruent with some previous research which reported that metal cations of weak Lewis acidity make the catalyst-substrate complexes unstable, while very acidic metal cations give the catalyst-substrate complexes which are too stable to undergo further reaction [131]. The effect of metals (Lewis acid centers) on increasing the total acidity of HPAs was also reported by Tao et al.[132] in a study that was aiming to fine-tune the synergistic Brønsted-Lewis acidic effects in heteropoly acid catalysts. In this study, Keggin type heteropoly acid (HPA) catalysts- HnPW11MO39 (M=Ti(IV), Cu(II), Al(III), Sn(IV), Fe(III), Cr(III), Zr(IV), and Zn(II); for Ti and Zr, the number of oxygen is 40)- were synthesized and applied in esterification and transesterification reactions. Moderated Lewis metals, such as Ti and Cu, displayed more influence on total acidity. In addition, it was also demonstrated that a Lewis metal in the form of an addenda atom (H5PW11TiO40) was less effective than those serving as counter cations (TixH3–4xPW12O40). A Brønsted–Lewis-surfactant-combined heteropoly acid (HPA) catalyst (C16TA)H4TiPW11O40 (C16TA= cetyltrimethylammonium) was also reported as an environmentally benign catalyst for esterification reaction [133]. The dual Brønsted-Lewis acidity coupled with the water tolerance property of this micellar HPA catalyst enabled it to achieve a high conversion efficiency of 94.7% in the esterification reaction of palmitic acid with methanol, under optimal conditions. The catalyst was stable during the reaction and could be recycled by a simple separation process. Highly active Brønsted-Lewis bifunctional heteropoly acids were prepared by partially exchanging Keggin heteropoly acid protons (i.e., H3PW12O40, H3PMo12O40, H4-SiW12O40) with Sn(II) cations, and subsequently tested in the transesterification of macauba oil with ethyl alcohol [134]. The catalytic activity was found to be significantly dependent on the amount of tin exchanged with the protons of HPAs, as well as on the nature of precursors (i.e., tin salts and heteropoly acids). The synergism between Brønsted and Lewis acidities was confirmed by comparing the activities of the precursor HPAs, tin salts, and their physical mixtures. Sn1.2H0.6PW12O40 displayed the highest activity amongst all investigated HPA salt catalysts, with an excellent fatty acid ethyl esters (FAEE) yield of ca. 100% (Table 1, Entry 24). This catalyst was efficiently recovered and could be repeatedly used after washing out the adsorbed FAEE or unreacted substrate molecules using tert-butyl alcohol. However, it should be noted that although exchanging large cations such as Zr, Ti, Sn and Zn into Keggin type HPAs may markedly enhance the stability of the resultant heteropolyacids, generally, the low surface area of these catalytic materials still limits their catalytic activities to attain high biodiesel yields under mild conditions. Gopinath et al. [135] tried to improve the surface area by synthesizing a novel solid acid catalyst based on mesoporous cesium exchanged tungstosilicic acid supported on Zr-KIT-6 (Cs-STA/ZK), via a hydrothermal method. Although the used reaction conditions were not very compelling for industrial biodiesel production, but the Cs-STA/ZK catalyst (SBET: 611 m2/g) displayed a better catalytic performance by achieving 98% conversion efficiency in both the esterification of oleic acid and transesterification of non-edible oils (Table 1, Entry 25). This performance was attributed to the higher BET surface area and strong interactions between Keggin units and –OH groups in Cs-STA/ZK( Fig. 10), which enabled the creation of a high density of acidic sites. Furthermore, apart from the conventional Brønsted-Lewis bifunctional heteropoly acids prepared by exchanging metal cations into HPA pristine structures, some other peculiar HPA-based Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional materials have been reported as solid acid catalysts for esterification and transesterification reactions. For instance, Keggin type heteropoly acid and ZrO2 functionalized ethane-bridged organosilica hollow nanospheres (H3PW12O40/ZrO2-Et-HNS) were prepared via sol-gel co-condensation route and applied as solid catalysts for the transesterification of yellow horn oil with methanol [136]. This study showed that the inherent strong Brønsted-and Lewis acidity enabled H3PW12O40/ZrO2-Et-HNS to promote the transesterification reaction at a fast rate. The unique hollow nanospherical morphology of these hybrid catalysts within shell thickness ( Fig. 11) coupled with their textural properties such as bimodal porous structure, larger BET surface area, high pore volume, and hydrophobic surface played a crucial role in facilitating the accessibility of the guest hydrophobic molecules to the acid sites, minimized the diffusion resistance, and increased the dispersion of the acidic sites throughout the hybrid catalysts. More importantly, the strong interaction between the Keggin unit and ZrO2 could inhibit the leaching of the acidic sites and enable H3PW12O40/ZrO2-Et-HNS catalysts to be reused at least three times without a significant loss of catalytic activity. Very recently, a novel solid Brönsted-Lewis acid catalyst (La-PW-SiO2/SWCNTs) based on the synergistic modification of H3PW12O40 (HPW) by single-walled carbon nanotubes with sidewall functionalized by hydroxyl groups (SWCNTs–OH) and La3+ was synthesized via the sol-gel method and tested for biodiesel synthesis from the esterification of oleic acid and methanol [137]. La-PW-SiO2/SWCNTs achieved a conversion efficiency of 93% after 8 h at 65 0C and could still reach 88.7% conversion after six catalytic cycles (Table 1, Entry 26). This high catalytic activity and stability were ascribed to the strong electron-withdrawing effect of La3+ on the π bond of SWCNTs, which could facilitate the formation of a large number of strong Lewis acidic sites. Overall, it is important to note that although the synthesis of Brönsted-Lewis bifunctional heteropoly acids seems to be an interesting approach for enhancing their acidic strength, further research efforts are still needed to improve their catalytic activity and stability for efficient and sustainable biodiesel production. 3.1.4 Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional zeolites Some types of zeolites, such as β zeolites, possess both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites within their structure and have been investigated as solid acid catalysts for biodiesel production. However, by and large, conventional zeolites suffer from poor catalytic activities in biodiesel production due to the internal diffusion limitations of the bulky reactant molecules (FFA/triglycerides) into the micropores of zeolites [138–140]. To address this major challenge of microporous zeolites, different strategies aiming at reducing the crystal size of a zeolite and enhancing the porosity (hierarchical/mesoporous range) have been tried to increase the accessibility of active sites and the rate of intra-crystalline diffusion. From this perspective, Zhang et. al. synthesized a hierarchically organized β zeolite by employing an organofunctionalized nanosilica as a silica source in a hydrothermal reaction [141]. This β zeolite was found to have a BEA topological structure consisting of self-sustaining macroscopic-sized zeolitic aggregates assembled from nanosized crystalline domains of the beta zeolite with intra-crystalline mesopores. A detailed characterization showed that this beta zeolite possessed the dual Brønsted and Lewis acidity, an extremely large external surface area, and adjustable mesoporosity. Although this hierarchical Beta zeolite exhibited higher catalytic activity for the transesterification of triolein in comparison to the conventional Beta zeolite; it is worth further research to optimize its mesoporous volume and surface hydrophobicity, two important parameters known to increase the accessibility and reduce the diffusion limitations of bulky lipids molecules to reach the zeolitic acid sites for maximum catalytic conversion. Similarly, a pillared mesoporous HMCM-36 zeolite synthesized using CTAB and silica as swelling and pillaring reagents, respectively, was applied as a bifunctional solid catalyst in the esterification of palmitic acid with methanol [142]. HMCM-36 zeolite featured a high BET surface area of (635 m2/g) and a high concentration of Brønsted (0.0343 mmol/g) and Lewis (0.0102 mmol/g) acidic sites. Impressively, the pillared HMCM-36 exhibited an excellent catalytic activity in the esterification of palmitic acid, and even outperformed many solid acid catalysts, such as HPA/SBA-15 and WOx/ZrO2, with the highest conversion efficiency (100%) and superior stability (Table 1, Entry 28), attributed to its high density of acidic sites and mesoporous structure. However, during this study, HMCM-36 was not tested in any transesterification reaction just to get a sense of its catalytic performance in the conversion of challenging bulky and hydrophobic molecules (triglycerides), normally involved in a typical biodiesel production process. Another study was conducted to compare the catalytic performance of four commercial zeolites: H-ZSM-5–30, H-ZSM-5–50, H-Y-5.2, and H-Y-60, as solid acid catalysts for the conversion of palmitic acid to methyl palmitate [143]. All these zeolites had both Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites, but the study showed that the difference in surface acidity did not influence the catalytic performance. On the other hand, there was a clear dependence of the catalytic activity on the porosity and hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance. This finding confirmed the critical role of large-size pores and surface wettability in facilitating the accessibility of active sites by reactant molecules and the desorption of product molecules. 3.1.5 Miscellaneous Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional materials In addition to the aforementioned Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional catalysts based on metal oxides, ionic liquids, heteropoly acids, and zeolites, which are even the most common categories of the Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctionality; some other materials belonging to this bifunctionality have been reported as potential solid acid catalysts for biodiesel production. For instance, acid-activated montmorillonites prepared by the activation with different H3PO4 concentrations were evaluated as heterogeneous catalysts for the esterification of lauric acid with methanol [144]. STx-1-P0.5M2h obtained by treating STx-1 with 0.5 H3PO4 in 2 h exhibited the highest catalytic activity in the esterification of lauric acid with a conversion efficiency of 96,7% and could be reused up to 4 cycles without any significant loss of activity or catalyst mass. This high catalytic activity and stability were ascribed to milder activation conditions which minimized the leaching of active species, thus improving the acidity and the strength of the double Brønsted-Lewis acidic sites in addition to providing structural and textural properties that were suitable for the esterification reaction. A solid acid with both Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites based on resorcinol-furaldehyde (RF) was synthesized from resorcinol-furaldehyde resin, hydroxyethylsulfonic acid, and copper hydroxyethylsulfonate [145]. This solid acid catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity and stability for biodiesel production from rapeseed oil containing high water and FFA contents insofar as to achieve more than 95% FAME yield after six catalytic cycles (Table 1, Entry 29). Lastly, a carbonaceous bifunctional magnetic solid acid catalyst bearing double Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites (Zr-CMC-SO3H@3Fe-C400) was synthesized via a four-step process consisting of (i) Fe metal ion chelation, (ii) calcination, (iii) metal (Zr) ion chelation, and embedding, and (iv) sulfonation [146]. More importantly, in synthesizing this solid acid catalyst, particular attention was paid to controlling the balance between magnetism and catalytic activity. (Zr-CMC-SO3H@3Fe-C400) efficiently catalyzed the esterification of oleic acid with 97% biodiesel yield, and the conversion of high acid value (AV) soybean oil with 95% biodiesel yield under mild conditions (Table 1, Entry 30). Moreover, the catalyst could be easily recovered and reused for up to five cycles with a slight loss of catalytic activity. However, the synthetic methods of the Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional materials described in this sub-section are quite complex and, certainly, need to be greatly simplified in the context of making biodiesel production more cost-effective. 3.2 Acid-base bifunctional solid catalysts for biodiesel production It has been reported that for large scale biodiesel production to be sustainable- that is to say: economically viable, socially acceptable, and environmentally friendly- the production processes must use low–cost oil feedstocks, such as non-food and waste oils, and the corresponding catalytic systems should be heterogeneous and able to catalyze both the esterification of FFA and transesterification of triglycerides simultaneously and efficiently [16,40,64,147]. Apart from the bifunctional solid acid catalysts bearing Brønsted and/Lewis acidic sites, acid-base bifunctional solid catalysts can also promote the esterification and transesterification reactions in a one-pot process. Fig. 12 shows a proposed general mechanism for the simultaneous esterification and transesterification process over a bifunctional acid-base catalyst. Interestingly, acid-base bifunctional catalysts present a compelling advantage over acid catalysts because a base-catalyzed transesterification is much faster than an acid-catalyzed counterpart, explaining why most industrial biodiesel production processes still prefer base catalysts [52,148]. To explore the cooperative effects of acidic and basic sites in a single catalytic material, different approaches such as random distribution of the active sites, placement of the active sites in immediate proximity, and most importantly, spatial compartmentalization/segregation of the two chemically incompatible active sites in different parts of a catalyst, have been used to synthesize acid-base bifunctional solid catalysts for one-pot biodiesel production, especially utilizing low-cost oil with high FFA and water content. The main acid-base bifunctional solid catalysts reported in the literature for biodiesel production include hybrid solid materials based on metal-organic frameworks( MOFs), hydrotalcites, biomass-derived materials, and mixed metal oxides. 3.2.1 Acid-base mixed oxides Solid mixed-metal oxides consist of two or more metal oxides and are mainly divided into three types: base, acid, and acid-base bifunctional mixed metal oxides. By and large, the objective of preparing the solid mixed-metal oxides catalysts is to enhance the basic and/or acid strength, improve the surface area, and increase the stability of these catalysts compared to single metal oxides [149]. For instance, CaO has been studied as a strong base catalyst with many potential advantages such as low cost and giving high catalytic activities under mild conditions. For biodiesel production via transesterification, however, CaO and Ca-based catalysts suffer from poor stability mainly caused by the leaching of Ca species. One of the strategies to improve the stability and reusability of CaO as a heterogeneous catalyst has been the formation of mixed/binary metal oxides, which apart from enhancing the alkalinity may also allow the synthesis of the acid-base bifunctional catalysts [151,152]. From this perspective, Kim et al. [153] prepared CaO– CeO2 and CaO–La2O3 mixed oxides and studied the effect of various acidic and basic support materials on the catalytic activity and deactivation mechanism of the supported catalysts for the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol. The study found that the metal composition and surface acidity (or basicity) of the supported catalysts played a significant role in determining the activity of the catalyst. Interestingly, the catalytic activity of CaO–La2O3 or CaO–CeO2 loaded on basic supports, such as La2O3 and CeO2, were much higher than the activities of the same materials loaded on acidic supports materials (ZSM-5 and TiO2), confirming that base catalysts promote the transesterification reaction much faster than acid counterparts. In addition, it was observed that FAME yields were negligible for the CaO–La2O3 and CaO–CeO2 supported on acidic materials. In explaining this observation, the authors stated that the interactions with the acidic supports resulted in the neutralization and leaching of the basic active sites which were supposed to promote the transesterification reaction rapidly. Inspired by the fact that the interactions of CaO with other oxides can reduce the leaching complication associated with Ca-based catalysts, Xie et al.[154] used the incipient impregnation method to prepare an acid-base bifunctional catalyst (CaO–MoO3–SBA-15) in which the acidic (MoO3) and basic (CaO) sites were dispersed on mesoporous SBA-15. In this study, a CaO–MoO3–SBA-15 catalyst with 40% of CaO–MoO3 and calcined at 823 K for 6 h achieved the highest conversion (83.2%) in the methanolysis of soybean oil with high stability ( Table 2, Entry 1). This superior stability was attributed to the interaction between the basic CaO and the acidic MoO3 active sites, and their high and stable dispersion on mesoporous SBA-15. On top of that, this acid-base bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst exhibited high tolerance to FFAs and water in the oil substrate. To be specific, for Soybean oil with 4% FFAs or 2% water content, the catalyst afforded a conversion efficiency of 80.6% or 78.6%, respectively. Similarly, another Ca-based bifunctional solid catalyst (CaO-La2O3) was synthesized via the co-precipitation method and applied for biodiesel production from high FFA Jatropha oil [155]. It was noticed that the co-precipitation of La with Ca enhanced the dispersion of CaO and eventually increased the concentration of surface acidic and basic sites which promoted the simultaneous esterification of FFA and transesterification of triglycerides from Jatropha oil. The CaO-La2O3 catalyst with a Ca/La atomic ratio of 8.0 achieved the highest biodiesel yield (98.76%) at 160 °C after 3 h (Table 2, Entry 2). However, the catalyst experienced Ca2+ leaching in the first catalytic cycle caused by some free CaO species which did not participate in the formation of the binary system. This was evinced by stable reusability in the next 4 cycles with reduced leaching of Ca2+ ion into the reaction medium. Furthermore, Endalew et al. [156] reported some acid-base solid catalytic systems for biodiesel production via simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions, consisting of a mixture of solid bases (CaO or Li-CaO) and a solid acid ((Fe2(SO4)3). CaO or Li-CaO:Fe2(SO4)3 in 2:1 ratio exhibited a quite high catalytic activity for biodiesel production from Jatropha curcas oil (JCO). The authors of this study claimed that Fe2(SO4)3 played an important role in avoiding soap formation by consuming FFAs in the esterification reaction before CaO or Li-CaO accelerated the transesterification of triglycerides. However, one may question how soap formation was completely avoided while using a physical mixture of the acid and base solid catalysts just in a single-step simultaneous esterification and transesterification process. Apart from calcium-based oxides, mixed oxides of other metals have also been reported as efficient solid catalysts for biodiesel production similarly due to their dual-acidic and basic active sites which can also catalyze the esterification of free fatty acids (FFAs) and transesterification of triglycerides (TGs) concurrently. What is more, these metal oxides can be easily modified to incorporate some additional properties able to tackle some adverse effects of impurities/by-products such as water. For instance, La2O3 possesses the acid-base character and has been used as a support for various other metal oxides to synthesize acid-base bifunctional catalysts with enhanced catalytic activity for tandem biodiesel catalysis. Zinc and lanthanum mixed oxides (ZnO-La2O3) with different Zn: La ratios were investigated as bifunctional solid acid-base catalysts for biodiesel production from unrefined or waste oils via simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions [157]. The catalyst with a 3:1 ratio of zinc to lanthanum was more tolerant to FFAs and water and achieved the highest FAME yield (96%) from unrefined or waste oils after 3 h (Table 2, Entry 3). This study found out that the strong interaction between zinc and lanthanum species enhanced the catalytic activity by increasing the density of acidic and basic sites at the surface of the mixed metal oxides catalysts. Another acid-base bifunctional catalyst, Bi2O3 supported on La2O3 (Bi2O3–La2O3), was synthesized by using the wet impregnation method and tested for biodiesel production from non-edible Jatropha curcas oil [158]. TPD-CO2 and TPD-NH3 measurements showed that Bi2O3 (1–7 wt%) modified La2O3 catalyst contained both acidic and basic sites. Nonetheless, only 3 BiLa and 5BiLa possessed the strongest basic and acidic strengths for efficient simultaneous transesterification of triglycerides and esterification of a high concentration of FFAs in the Jatropha oil. The 5BiLa with the highest surface area achieved the highest conversion of 93% with good reusability (conversion of 87% after 3 successive runs), under optimal reaction conditions (Table 2, Entry 4). Zirconium oxides in acidic or basic forms can also be modified to synthesize their corresponding acid-base bifunctional catalysts. For instance, Omar et al.[150] prepared some alkaline metal-modified zirconia catalysts (Mg/ZrO2, Ca/ZrO2, Sr/ZrO2, and Ba/ZrO2) through wet impregnation of alkaline nitrate salts on zirconia. In biodiesel production from waste cooking oil, Sr/ZrO2 exhibited the highest catalytic activity among all the other investigated catalysts for simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions, attributed to the optimal concentration of acidic and basic sites as well as its pore volume, pore diameter, and surface area which were more favorable for the conversion of bulky FFA and triglycerides molecules into biodiesel molecules (FAMEs). Alhassan et al.[159] prepared a ferric–manganese doped sulfated zirconia nanoparticle solid catalyst (Fe2O3-MnO-SO4/ZrO2, abbreviated as FMSZ) through the impregnation method followed by calcination at 600 OC for 3 h. The study revealed that the dispersed Fe2O3 and MnO particles played a crucial role in preventing the agglomeration of zirconia particles, leading to higher surface area and acidity, which in turn enhanced the catalytic activity of FMSZ for biodiesel production from waste cooking oil compared to zirconia (Z) and sulfated zirconia (SZ). Under the same optimal reaction conditions (Table 2, Entry 5), FAME yields for FMSZ, Z, and SZ were 96.5%, 88.0%, and 43.3%, respectively. Needless to say, FMSZ outperformed the two other catalysts owing to its strong acid and basic active centers which were able to efficiently convert FFAs and triglycerides from waste cooking oil into biodiesel molecules. Moreover, the FMSZ catalyst maintained nearly the same FAME yield up to 6 catalytic runs, demonstrating its excellent reusability as a potential acid-base bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst for biodiesel production. In another study, Mn@MgO-ZrO2 synthesized by a modified route involving co-precipitation and incipient impregnation was also applied as a bifunctional acid-base metallic oxide catalyst to valorize waste Phoenix dactylifera L. Kernel oil into biodiesel [160]. The characterization of Mn@MgO-ZrO2 revealed that the modification of the amphoteric ZrO2 with magnesium and manganese oxides increased the strength of acidic and basic sites in the mixed oxide, which can promote biodiesel production via simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions. A balanced concentration of the active sites and a structure with a suitable pore size enabled Mn@MgO-ZrO2 to obtain a maximum biodiesel yield of 96.4% after 4 h at 90 0C (Table 2, Entry 6). Similarly, other acid-base bifunctional solid catalysts based on various metal oxides, such as MnCeOx [161], Na2O (20 wt%)/CNTs [162], MgZnAlO [163], Mo-Mn/γ-Al2O3-15 wt%MgO [164], Ca-B(700) [165], Zn8 @Fe-C400 [166], and SrO–ZnO/Al2O3 [167] , have been reported as efficient solid catalysts for biodiesel production from high FFA oils via concurrent esterification and transesterification reactions. However, it is worth mentioning that although there have been tremendous research efforts in improving the catalytic activity and stability of acid-base mixed oxides as bifunctional solid catalysts for biodiesel production, generally, the lack of suitable porous structures and the hydrophilic nature of these solid catalysts do not facilitate the diffusion and adsorption of the bulky organic substrates (triglycerides) involved in biodiesel production, thus necessitating harsh reaction conditions, such as long reaction time and/or high temperature, which may not seem interesting for their industrial catalytic application. Furthermore, very recently, Isaacs et al. [58] prepared a spatially orthogonal hierarchical porous acid-base catalyst (SZ/MgO/MM-SBA-15) and applied it for biodiesel production via simultaneous esterification and transesterification as a study of the antagonistic acid-base catalysis. In addition, the authors brought in another interesting aspect of controlling the sequence in which reactants interact with individual active sites, termed substrate channeling, normally encountered in biological catalysis. The study made use of hierarchical porosity and metallosurfactant templating to spatially segregate acidic and basic sites as two chemically incompatible catalytic sites. To this end, acidic sulfated zirconia (SZ) monolayer was grown inside macropores of a hierarchical SBA-15 silica framework, while basic MgO NPs were introduced into the connected mesopores as shown in Fig. 13. Low-field NMR relaxation-exchange correlation experiments ( Fig. 14) provided strong evidence of the substrate channeling from a bulk reaction medium into macropores where the esterification of FFA took place over SZ and subsequent molecular transport from macropores to mesopores where the transesterification reaction mainly occurred over MgO NPs. Needless to say, although SZ/MgO/MM-SBA-15 did not achieve high FAME yields, its architecture is very suitable for the design and synthesis of acid-base bifunctional catalysts, especially for efficient biodiesel production from high FFA oil feedstocks. 3.2.2 Hydrotalcites Hydrotalcite and hydrotalcite- type compounds such as layered double hydroxides (LDHs) constitute a group of brucite-like layered materials with the general formula of [M2+ (1-x) M3+ x (OH)2] x+( Ax /n) n-⋅yH2O, where M2+ ( Mg2+, Ni2+,...), M3+ (Al3+, Fe3+,...) represent divalent and trivalent cations in the octahedral sites, while ( Ax /n) n-: CO3 2-, NO3 -, Cl-, … is the counter anion located in the interlayer space for balancing the residual positive charge of the hydroxide layers which results from the substitution of M2+ by M3+, as shown in Fig. 15. These materials have been used as solid base catalysts and support/precursors of base supported metal catalysts for various organic transformations [168–172] on account of their strong basic character, originating from strong Brønsted/Lewis basic sites such as OH- and O2- incorporated in the interlayer space [173–175]. Moreover, taking an example of hydrotalcite with chemical formula: Mg4Al2CO3(OH)12.4(H2O), it was revealed that the activated form also displays Lewis acidity mainly provided by Al3+ cations in Al3+–O2-–Mg2+ species. The strength of this acidity depends on the nature of cations and anions, the M2+/M3+ ratio, the synthesis method (co-precipitation or sol-gel method), and the activation conditions [169,176]. This acid-base character of hydrotalcites and their corresponding oxides (Al-O-Mg) has attracted great interest from many researchers to investigate their catalytic application for biodiesel production. For instance, quintinite-3 T (Q-3 T), a family member of LDHs with an Al: Mg ratio of 0.5 prepared by sol-gel process, exhibited excellent catalytic activity for biodiesel production from coffee waste streams [177]. Irrespective of FFA content (0–30%) in the oil, Q-3 T achieved 98.97% conversion under optimized conditions (Table 2, Entry 12), outperforming many known solid catalysts such as calcium ethoxide, propyl sulfonic acid SBA-15, and hydrotalcite with Al: Mg ratio of 0.33. The superior catalytic performance of Q-3 T resulted from its double acidic and basic active sites which concurrently converted FFAs and TGs into biodiesel. Activated Mg-Al hydrotalcite (HT-Ca) nanoparticles (< 45 nm), prepared through co-precipitation and hydrothermal activation with aqueous Ca(OH)2 solution, were also applied as a solid catalyst for one-pot biodiesel production from crude oils with high acid value (AV) without pretreatment [178]. A comprehensive catalyst characterization indicated that the HT-Ca catalyst displayed acid-base bifunctionality originating from Mg4Al2(OH)14.3 H2O, Mg2Al(OH)7, and AlO(OH) nanocrystals. To evaluate the effect of FFAs on HT-Ca catalyst in the transesterification reaction, the catalyst achieved 92.9% biodiesel yield from soybean oil with a high AV of 12.1 mg KOH/g compared to 93.4% biodiesel yield from Jatropha AV of 6.3, demonstrating that apart from the triglycerides transesterification, the HT-Ca catalyst was also able to convert FFAs into biodiesel through the esterification reaction. However, the HT-Ca catalyst did not display good stability mainly due to the loss of active sites and their deactivation by glycerol adsorption. Other acid-base bifunctional solid catalysts based on hydrotalcites have also been reported for biodiesel production from high FFA oils [171,179,180], but generally, the synthetic methods of these catalytic materials are complex and time-consuming, a challenge that may hinder their industrial catalytic application. 3.2.3 Acid-base bifunctional hybrid catalysts based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), also known as porous coordination polymers (PCPs), are porous crystalline materials composed of metal or metal-cluster nodes and bridging organic linkers extended in two or, more typically, three dimensions [181,182]. MOFs have attracted a lot of interest as potential nanoporous materials for heterogeneous catalysis mainly due to their special characteristics including but not limited to the high surface area, highly ordered structure, tunable pore sizes, and tailorable functionalities [183–185]. The active sites within MOF-based catalysts can be inherent in the frameworks (e.g. metal centers with unsaturated coordination environments) or generated by post-synthetic methods like in the case of catalytic functional groups attached to the organic linkers of the frameworks, or other catalytic species (molecules, metals, etc.) encapsulated in the pores [185–187]. From this perspective, hybrid solid catalysts based on MOFs bearing both acidic and basic actives sites have been synthesized and tested as heterogeneous catalysts for one-pot biodiesel production using oil substrates with high FFA and water content. For instance, Jeon et al. [188] functionalized the surface of zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) nanoparticles with a Keggin-type HPA in imidazolium medium to form a hybrid ZIF-8/HPA, which was applied as an acid-based bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst for biodiesel production through transesterification of rapeseed oil with methanol. ZIF-8/HPA displayed a hierarchical structure with a large surface area and strong interconnectivity of its constituents, leading to a thin-wrinkled HPA shell at the surface of rhombic dodecahedral ZIF-8 core crystals. A strong ON hybrid bonding through an electrostatic effect in the hybrid ZIF-8/HPA ( Fig. 16) provided good stability at high temperatures in different types of solvents. Notably, ZIF-8/HPA materials displayed the acid-base bifunctional character with HPA and a part of the Zn in ZIF-8 as acid sites and the imidazolate as basic sites. By optimizing the HPA concentration from 0.05 to 0.5 g, HZN-2 functionalized with 0.1 g of HPA displayed the highest catalytic activity with a maximum FAME yield of 98.02% along with high recyclability at 200 °C after 2 h (Table 2, Entry 16). Similarly, very recently, Cheng et al. [189] synthesized HPW/ZIF-67 bifunctional hybrid catalyst by modifying ZIF-67 with phosphotungstic acid (HPW). The characterization results showed that the proportion of CoN bonds in ZIF-67 decreased from 32.4% to 21.7% due to the breakage of CoN bond by HPW and the resultant N- extremities of imidazolate ligands subsequently formed WON bonds with HPW. Similar to ZIF-8/HPA [188], these strong WON bonds were responsible for the high stability and reusability of the HPW/ZIF-67 bifunctional hybrid catalyst. Interestingly, the released coordinative unsaturated Co cations and N- extremities enhanced both the Brønsted acid and Lewis acid-base properties of this novel bifunctional catalyst. To be more specific, at the optimum HPW/ZIF-67 ratio of 0.25, the L/B ratio increased from 0.1 to 0.66 and the Lewis basic sites increased from 0.45 mmol/g to 4.53 mmol/g, due to the WON strong bonds in HPW/ZIF-67 = 0.25 compared to the pristine ZIF-67. This strong acid-base character coupled with a large surface area led to a high catalytic activity for biodiesel production from microalgal lipids via simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions. HPW/ZIF-67 = 0.25 showed an excellent conversion efficiency of 98.5% compared to 72.7% over pure ZIF-67 catalyst. Moreover, HPW/ZIF-67 = 0.25 displayed good stability and reusability because 91.3% conversion efficiency could still be achieved after 6 cycles (Table 2, Entry 17). It should be noted that although MOF-based solid catalysts with the acid-base bifunctionality possess some attractive properties such as high surface area and high density of active sites, the microporous domain of MOFs usually limit their catalytic activities for biodiesel production due to the diffusion limitation of bulky FFAs and TGs molecules to access actives sites [190,191], subsequently requiring high reaction temperature and/or long reaction time to obtain significant conversion efficiencies. In addition to MOFs/HPAs hybrid systems, MOFs have also been used as high surface and porous materials to support other acid or base monofunctional groups for the synthesis of various acid-base bifunctional MOF hybrid catalysts for biodiesel production [192–194]. A series of UiO-66(Zr)-structured solid catalysts were prepared and subsequently applied for biodiesel production via esterification of various fatty acids with MeOH and EtOH [192]. During this study, it was found out that UiO-66(Zr)-NH2 exhibited superior catalytic activity compared to UiO-66(Zr) thanks to the acid-base bifunctional character of UiO-66(Zr)-NH2 provided by the amino group (Brønsted base sites) and the zirconium center (Lewis acid site). During the esterification reactions, Zr Lewis acid sites which are present in both UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH2 played a role in adsorbing the FFAs, thus increasing the electrophilic character of the carboxylic carbon atom. On the other hand, although the –NH2 groups in UiO-66-NH2 were not basic enough to deprotonate ROH into RO-, the double activation mechanism by forming hydrogen-bonded adducts could increase the nucleophilic character of the O atom of the alcohol, and ultimately favor the condensation with the activated carboxylic carbon of the fatty acid.
