This dual activation mechanism whereby mild and close acid-base pairs provide superior catalytic activity compared to individual strong acid or basic sites was also reported in other research works [61,186]. 3.2.4 Miscellaneous acid-base bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts An acid-base bifunctional catalyst based on HPA nanocatalysts was prepared by the self-assembly of lysine (an amino acid with double NH2 groups) as basic sites and dodecaphosphotungstates (HPA) as acidic sites [195]. In addition, the amino acid functional group could react with HPA molecules for the formation of amphiphilic molecules with submicron structures and a rich range of shapes and sizes. The acid and base strengths could be modulated by varying the amounts of the two components (HPW and lysine). In comparison with HPW, Lysine, and LYHPW2; Ly2HPW exhibited the highest catalytic activity for biodiesel production from Eruca Sativa Gars (ESG) oil with extra myristic acid (20 wt%) via simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions. This superior catalytic performance of LYHPW2 was particularly attributed to the optimal ratio of the acid-base active sites as well as hydrophobic surfaces and open surroundings which could overcome the blockage of the acidic centers inside the pore structure of the catalyst. What is more, the leaching test showed that ly2HPW had excellent stability to the extent it could be reused up to five catalytic cycles without any significant loss of activity (Table 2, Entry 18). However, it is important to mention that although no attempt was made to compare Ly2HPW to other solid catalysts for biodiesel production, it is fair to rate its catalytic activity as just moderate. In fact, during the synthesis of Ly2HPW some of the acid and basic sites neutralized each other, leading to moderate acid and basic strengths of the resulting amphiphilic molecules which eventually limited the catalytic activity of Ly2HPW. Furthermore, a Zn coordination polymer with formula [Zn(4,4’-bipy)(OAc)2]n prepared by reacting Zn acetate and 4,4’-bipyridine in ethanol, was also applied as an acid-base bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst for biodiesel production from soybean oil [196]. NH3 and CO2-TPD techniques revealed that the catalyst had the acid-base character provided by Zn+ ions (acidic sites) and nitrogen atoms of 4,4’-bipyridine linkage ligand (basic sites). However, by comparing [Zn(4,4’-bipy)(OAc)2]n with another coordination polymer [Zn(BTC)] prepared from Zn(CH3COO)2. 2 H2O and 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (BTC), it was concluded that although both [Zn(4,4’-bipy)(OAc)2]n and Zn(BTC) exhibited an acidic character, the higher basicity of [Zn(4,4’-bipy)(OAc)2]n was mainly responsible for its superior catalytic activity during the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol. Although it demanded high temperature (180 oC) which is not suitable for its industrial catalytic application, [Zn(4,4’-bipy)(OAc)2]n achieved a 98% oil conversion efficiency just after 2 h and exhibited high stability because it could maintain nearly the same activity up to five consecutive catalytic cycles (Table 2, Entry 19). Very recently, an Iron (II) impregnated double-shelled hollow mesoporous silica (Fe/DS-HMS-NH2) fabricated using a two-step condensation technique was reported as an acid-base bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst for biodiesel production from degummed palm oil (DPO), a low-quality oil [197]. Fe/DS-HMS-NH2 has a double shell structure ( Fig. 17) with acid-base active sites spatially isolated in the two shells to be able to promote, in a one-pot process, the two chemical reactions involved in biodiesel production from low-quality oils. Indeed, the amino groups (-NH2) were placed in the inner shell (22 nm thickness) as basic sites to promote the transesterification reaction of DPO triglycerides, while the divalent iron (Fe(II)) was impregnated in the outer layer (13 nm thickness) as a strong Lewis acid to esterify FFAs from the DPO. What is more, Fe/DS-HMS-NH2 has a specific surface area of 782.84 m2/g with a pore volume of 0.64 cm3/g. Under optimized conditions (Table 2, Entry 20), this acid-base bifunctional catalyst achieved a maximum biodiesel yield of 85.36% after 4.5 h at 60 OC, which could stay above 80% after three consecutive catalytic cycles. It is worth mentioning that although Fe/DS-HMS-NH2 was designed and synthesized with a hollow-core structure enabling spatial separation of the active sites, a suitable structure of an acid/base bifunctional solid catalyst for efficient biodiesel production via simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions, its catalytic activity and stability were not outstanding for its industrial application. In addition to its attractive textural properties such as high surface area and mesoporous nature, it is worth further to render its surface hydrophobic because during biodiesel production this property can increase both catalytic activity and stability by enhancing the adsorption of oleophilic substrates and desorption of hydrophilic products (water and glycerol) which may deactivate the active sites [43]. Lastly, motivated by the potential advantages of bio-waste derived solid catalysts such as being cheap, abundant, easily available, and eco-friendly, some research groups reported the preparation of solid catalysts with the acid-base bifunctionality from biomass waste materials such as palm kernel shell [198], chicken eggshell [199,200], and angel wing shell [201]. These biowaste-based bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts exhibited quite significant catalytic activities and stabilities for biodiesel production from high FFA oils sources. However, more research efforts are still needed to develop more efficient bio-waste-derived solid catalysts for making biodiesel production highly cost-effective and environmentally benign. 4 Conclusion and outlook One of the alternative renewable and cleaner sources of energy currently being pursued is biodiesel. However, biodiesel’s wide application is still hampered by its high cost of production mainly caused by the use of refined and edible oil feedstocks. Encouragingly, unlike the conventional homogeneous base catalysts, solid catalysts can provide a green, efficient, and economical pathway for biodiesel production using low-quality oil feedstocks such as waste cooking oil. This review provides a summary of advances in the synthesis of bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts for efficient biodiesel production and emphasizes the role of the synergistic effect of the double active sites in enhancing the catalytic activity compared to monofunctional acid/base catalysts. The review starts from the recent progress on Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional solid catalysts such as supported ionic liquids, metal oxides, heteropoly acids, and zeolites for biodiesel production. Brønsted-Lewis bifunctional solid catalysts have proved to be more active in biodiesel production from low-quality oil feedstocks via simultaneous esterification of FFA and transesterification of triglycerides. Indeed, many studies have revealed that Brønsted acids exhibit higher catalytic activity in the esterification reaction, while Lewis acids are more active in the transesterification reaction. Therefore, combining both the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in a single catalytic material increases the acid strength and provides a synergistic effect, which altogether could enhance the activity of the bifunctional catalysts. Apart from Brønsted-Lewis acid bifunctional catalysts, this review also explores advances in the development of acid-base bifunctional solid catalysts for biodiesel production. These catalysts present a very compelling advantage because it is well proven that a base-catalyzed transesterification is much faster than an acid-catalyzed counterpart. Although accommodating the two chemically incompatible active sites in a single catalytic material requires meticulous work to avoid their neutralization/deactivation, a well-designed acid-base bifunctional solid catalyst can produce biodiesel from low-quality oil via concurrent FFA esterification and triglycerides transesterification more efficiently. Various types of acid-base bifunctional solid materials, namely mixed metal oxides, hydrotalcites, MOFs-based hybrids, and biomass-based materials reported as solid catalysts for biodiesel production are also thoroughly discussed in this review article. Although much effort has been made to develop bifunctional acid/base solid catalysts as a special category of catalysts that holds great potential for efficient biodiesel production from low-cost/low-quality oil feedstocks via a one-pot process, by and large, some major challenges listed here below still need to be effectively addressed to improve the overall performance of these solid catalysts for their industrial application in biodiesel production: ▪ Although the synergy of Bronsted-Lewis acid sites or acid-base sites has been reported, detailed mechanism studies are still rare. Consequently, there is still a lack of the design principle for the preparation of efficient bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts that could perform under mild conditions with feedstocks near stoichiometric ratio. ▪ A high number of the reported solid catalysts still suffer from poor stability and reusability, a challenge usually originating from active site deactivation, poisoning, and/or leaching in the reaction medium. ▪ Most of the synthetic methods are very complex, costly, and are inefficient vis-à-vis the principles of green chemistry which should guide heterogeneous catalysis. To design and synthesize efficient, robust, stable, and cost-effective bifunctional acid/base solid catalysts for sustainable biodiesel production, future studies should consider the following strategies: ▪ First of all, model bifunctional acid/base solid catalysts with a controllable density of the active sites should be designed to elucidate the structure/composition and activity relationship. ▪ Bifunctional solid catalysts with high surface area and high concentration of the acid-base or Brønsted-Lewis acid sites at optimized ratios should be designed to maximize the cooperative catalysis. ▪ To address the mass transfer resistance which usually limits the catalytic activity of solid catalysts, and by extension, requires the use of harsh reaction conditions; the bifunctional solid catalysts should ideally possess well-defined nanostructures able to ease accessibility of the active sites by the bulky FFAs and TGs substrate molecules. ▪ The surface hydrophobicity of bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts should be fine-tuned to enhance both the adsorption of oleophilic substrates involved in biodiesel production (TGs and FFAs), and the desorption of water (the hydrophilic by-product of FFA esterification) which apart from causing the hydrolysis of the final biodiesel molecules may also destroy the catalyst structure. This will simultaneously enhance the catalytic activity, stability, and reusability. ▪ To improve the stability and catalytic activity of the acid-base bifunctional solid catalysts, the two chemically incompatible/ antagonistic active sites should be spatially isolated/segregated to preclude their neutralization and deactivation. What is more, the catalysts should be designed to enable the control of the sequence in which the reactants interact with individual active sites (substrate challenging). This will prevent the poisoning of basic active sites by FFAs, and ultimately optimize the cooperative catalysis between acidic and basic sites in the bifunctional catalysts. ▪ To develop efficient, facile, and environmentally friendly methods for high-performance bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts for biodiesel production, the combination of existing synthetic methods for inorganic, organic, and nanomaterials should be considered. ▪ Last but not least, waste-based materials should be considered for the preparation of the bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts as another potential strategy to further reduce the overall cost of biodiesel production. coredata.dc:description: Biodiesel has attracted significant attention as a potential renewable and environmentally friendly substitute for petroleum-derived diesel fuel. Conventionally, commercial biodiesel is produced via liquid base-catalyzed transesterification of triglycerides components of oil/fat with short-chain alcohols. However, homogeneous base catalysts are very sensitive to free fatty acids present in low-quality oil feedstocks, requiring additional acid pretreatment and neutralization steps which not only cause environmental pollution but also increase the overall cost of biodiesel production. Encouragingly, solid catalysts can provide a green, efficient, and economical pathway for biodiesel production using low-cost oil feedstocks such as waste cooking oil. The present review discusses recent advances in the synthesis of bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts for sustainable biodiesel production with a focus on solid catalysts bearing acid-base bifunctionality or Brønsted-Lewis dual acidity and the synergistic effect of the active sites for simultaneous esterification of free fatty acids and transesterification of triglycerides. Furthermore, this review article also provides future research directions that can guide scientists to address research gaps hampering the synthesis of effective bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts for sustainable biodiesel production.
coredata.dc:title: Review of advances in bifunctional solid acid/base catalysts for sustainable biodiesel production
